title: Creating PublicSpaces | Digital Government: Research and Practice

last_post.content:
Very excited to have published this new article, "Creating PublicSpaces" with my friends Jose Van Dijck and Geert-Jan Boegarts about how the Netherlands is taking digital public infrastructure and "values-led institutions" seriously, in ACM DGOV. https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3582578

GJ is the founder of PublicSpaces, a remarkable coalition of public broadcasters, cultural institutions and other public institutions in the Netherlands, seeking alternatives to commercial, surveillant and closed software.

José and I both advise the group, and we realized we were looking at an interesting market sector: organizations whose values conflict with traditional business models to produce and support software and other digital infrastructures.

GJ and PublicSpaces have created a model that helps orgs assess what software they're dependent on, how it conflicts with their values and how they might move onto more ideologically consistent infrastructures.

title: Paraphrasing evades detectors of AI-generated text, but retrieval is an effective defense

last_post.content:
RT @kalpeshk2011@twitter.com

To detect text written by LMs like #ChatGPT, many methods have recently emerged: DetectGPT, watermarks, GPTZero.

We present a paraphrasing attack that can drop their detection rates to <10%.

To defend against it, we propose detection with retrieval.
https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.13408
🧵👇

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/kalpeshk2011/status/1639273935719022593

+ I posted a preprint describing the math and thinking behind the software over at https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.11312.pdf

title: Scaling Laws for Neural Language Models

last_post.content:
I'm baffled by the “Scaling Laws for Neural Language Models” paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2001.08361

They claim to find power laws for the loss L ~ 1/N^a, where N is the number of params/data/compute.

However, all plots look like below. That's obviously a log decay, not a PL! 👀

They squeeze a tiny range — less than a decade — on the y-axis, and put on a log-scale. But on a linear-log it would look nearly identical. Basic log-log fail!

A scaling of the type L ∝-log(N) would be far more realistic, and the interpretation is *radically* different.

In other words, in order for the loss to decay by a constant, the number of parameters/data/compute need to be multiplied by a proportional constant.

This means that the number of parameters/dataset/compute need to keep growing *exponentially* for steady progress to be seen!

title: Fundamentals of Generative Large Language Models and Perspectives in Cyber-Defense

The first public CYD report on implications of LLMs for cyber-defense and cyber-security is out.

It's really interesting to see alternative publishing approaches surface and develop. Organisations like ResearchEquals and Octopus are rethinking the idea that a publication consists of a single item, the article: instead, these platforms focus more holistically on the research process and allow the deposit of individual research objects that may or may not feed into a formal article later on.

https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-00861-0

Popular messaging apps like #WhatsApp and #Signal notify the sender when a message has been delivered.

Did you know that you can use this RTT (Round Trip Time) to triangulate the geographic location of the receiver?

Join me in today's episode of #WhitepaperWednesday as we explore the tactics of extracting user locations from mobile instant messengers.

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.10523.pdf

title: Right the docs: Characterising voice dataset documentation practices used in machine learning

last_post.content:
Announcing a new #paper #preprint co-authored with my #PhD supervisor, @eltwilliams:

Right the docs: Characterising #voice #dataset #documentation practices used in #ML

https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10721

This paper combines two methods - semi-structured interviews and documentation analysis, and identifies ML practices used with voice dataset documentation, the tradeoffs ML practitioners make, and the roles ML practitioners have. It concludes the voice dataset documentation practices are immature and makes recommendations for next steps.

title: Negativity drives online news consumption - Nature Human Behaviour

last_post.content: “Although positive words were slightly more prevalent than negative words, we found that negative words in news headlines increased consumption rates (and positive words decreased consumption rates). For a headline of average length, each additional negative word increased the click-through rate by 2.3%. Our results contribute to a better understanding of why users engage with online media.” https://www.nature.com/articles/s41562-023-01538-4

RT @MattMikula
Magnushammer, a transformer-based approach for premise selection smashes Sledgehammer, the most mature symbolic solver!

Combined with an LLM, it achieves SoTA performance on the PISA theorem proving benchmark (57% -> 71%).

Paper: http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04488

last_post.content:
RT @rasbt
PaLM is a really interesting decoder-style language model that I initially kind of ignored when it was published last year: https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.02311

Turns out PaLM has 7 interesting architecture improvements over GPT.

1/9

I use a classification system that's more abstract. Cognitive biases are a consequence for compensating for (1) limited memory (2) needing to act fast (3) lack of meaning and (4) information overload.

title: Memory Augmented Large Language Models are Computationally Universal

last_post.content:
Sure, LLMs are a kind of game of guess the next word through statistical inference - but I think that view does maybe underestimate things a bit.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04589

This fairly straightforward paper shows the construction of a universal turing machine through a memory augmented LLM (generic, not trained to this task).

The result is maybe not surprising (IMO), but more the point is that with careful prompting and feedback loops that quite generic computation is entirely possible.

title: Constitutional AI: Harmlessness from AI Feedback

last_post.content:
"As AI systems become more capable, we would like to enlist their help to supervise other AIs. We experiment with methods for training a harmless AI assistant through self-improvement, without any human labels identifying harmful outputs. The only human oversight is provided through a list of rules or principles, and so we refer to the method as 'Constitutional AI'."

[2212.08073] Constitutional AI: Harmlessness from AI Feedback
https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08073#
